title: Chapter Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Las Vegas, NV)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was a grueling process that betrayed both a lack of urgency and coordination, lasting over six months since the initial job posting. Between half a dozen interviews conducted over that time, I spent around 20 active hours interviewing, preparing, or completing materials asked for by the hiring committee. Two months into the process, I was informed that Sierra Club National required the chapter to keep the job posted until enough candidates of diversity had applied. I respected that choice, as the green movement absolutely has a diversity problem that needs addressing. I assumed things would move more quickly once they had gathered more candidates, however, that was not the case. The second to last interview I did included a one hour timed assignment which consisted of creating the chapter's fundraising budget, plans, and estimating the revenue generated, without any background information. All in all, an inordinate amount of work went into this interview process, only for the team to decide, in the end, to cancel the position and repost it at a higher salary in the hopes to attract better talent. Given the complete disfunction of the hiring process, I can't imagine a candidate with the skills they are looking for accepting a low wage and enduring such a tedious and convoluted process.
Interview Questions: Questions were fairly routine and related to experience organizing and running campaigns, lobbying, volunteer management, budget management, and fundraising/development experience and strategies.

title: Operador Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sierra Club (Buenos Aires)
Interview Descriptions: Buen trato buena calidad humana, buen feedback. Excelente trato cordial. La persona encargada se comportó acordé a lo que se esperaría en una entrevista del tipo de presa nombrada. Esperando novedades al respecto
Interview Questions: Cargos. Experiencia. Trabajo en equipo. Colaboraciones. Aptitudes.

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Newark, NJ)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was with a group of 4 people. They each asked me a question about my prior experiences and how I would approach situations in the position. The interview was conducted over Zoom.
Interview Questions: Do you have prior experience with posting on social media? Do you have an example?

title: Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Took 5 months. Applied online in August. Process was slow. First round was written response, second was interview with manager, third was an assignment, and fourth was interview with entire team.
Interview Questions: How do you learn new skills and how do you use them? how do you present outcomes to non technical people?

title: Communications Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: Several rounds of very short interviews, with one longer at end. Asked hypothetical questions about campaigns. 4 months between app and first interview, then all interviews happened quickly. Unsure if the short (~10 minute) interviews made it easier or harder than the usual.
Interview Questions: How would you organize a campaign to stop a local gas plant form being built.

title: Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: 1. Answer a few short answer questions about why you want to work there 2. Phone screening with hiring manager and a member of the hiring committee 3. Analytical excel task 4. Interview with entire hiring committee
Interview Questions: What is a project you've worked on that is relevant to this role?

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: submitted resume on website and received an email a few days later saying I had been selected to move forward in the interview process. Signed up for a zoo phone call slot 30 minutes long. Second round interviews are in a few weeks.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you had a difficult situation with a customer and how did you deal with it.

title: Conflict Coach Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Lengthy; in the end it was to be 7 months of jumping through hoops (I jumped for 4).  The manager thought she was a therapist. I'm a real therapist. She isn't a therapist.
Interview Questions: Tell us a time you had to resolve a workplace conflict (I'm paraphrasing).

title: Content Strategist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: I had three interviews in total, one with direct managers, one with department head, and one with union members. All online/video interviews. Entire process took 6 months from application to offer.
Interview Questions: Asked about my strategies for managing projects

title: Programmer/Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Initial phone screening was 30 minutes long, with the hiring manager. 

The second round was a 1-hour panel interview with the entire team, conducted via Google Meet. Team members took turns asking questions.

There was good communication between interview rounds about next steps and status.
Interview Questions: Initial phone screening consisted of outlining the hiring process and hiring schedule as well as asking questions about specific skills and past application of those skills. The next round was more focused on communication and problem-solving/interpersonal skills.

title: Communications  and Outreach Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Trenton, NJ) in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions: Took about a month after submitting an application to hear back. I was to submit ~500 word responses to five different questions based on the role and my experiences. About three weeks later, I had a ~45 minute phone interview with 3 team members. A month later followed yet another interview, this time over Zoom, with three more team members. Two weeks later, I was invited to a final in-person interview at the office with the same group of interviewers plus two more team members. I had to prepare an outreach and communcations plan, which took a few hours to do. Took two weeks after that to hear back that I didn't get an offer. Over three months later between three interviews and two written tasks I was stuck in the same spot. Why it took so long and why there were so many separate tasks and interviews I don't know- a waste of an applicant's time that deterred me from seeking employment at this organization.
Interview Questions: How do your personal ethics play in to your professional life?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Dec 2021 - Submitted Application via website.
Jan 2022 - Hiring Manager sent questionnaire which I completed and returned.
Feb 2022 - 30 minute screening  with the Hiring Manager and the individual who still held the position.   The two asked questions - which were about the same as what was included in the questionnaire for which I had already provided written responses the month prior. A majority of my responses were cut short as the hiring manager insisted on asking each question but did not want to exceed the 30 minute time slot. I managed to ask a typical question at the end of the call, the answer provided by the current development staff member suggested a lack of modernized nonprofit development experience.  I did not receive communication of any kind following the screening phone call.  
April 2022 - Position opening appears to be heavily promoted again.  
Leadership can't advance the organizational mission and revenue if they can't even get out of their own way.
Interview Questions: Share an example of a successful fundraising campaign from start to finish.

title: Associate Director Legislative & Administrative Advocacy Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was average and consisted of two separate interviews. One preliminary talk with the hiring director and then another interview with the DC office. However, they asked to see a writing sample once I was a finalist in the hiring process and when I sent in my writing sample, they never contacted me again. I thought this was odd because up until that point they were communicative and then just ghosted me at the very end of the process.
Interview Questions: What challenges can you foresee in a position like this? How would you deal with conflicting opinions or positions on an issue?

title: Recruiting Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: After submitting an online application, an HR representative will send an e-mail with several short-answer questions that require 150-word answers. The responses need to be sent within a week before they will speak with you.
Interview Questions: 1. What about the Sierra Club's approach and mission excite you the most? 2. What role do see Sierra Club playing in the social justice movement and how do you see their mission aligning with the role? 3. Briefly describe a project or initiative you participated in that you are proud to share. Be specific. 4. Talk about your experience. 5. Submit a brief statement that will enable us to understand the contribution your personal background would make to our team.

title: Conservation Technician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: It was very drawn out. I really wanted the job but it had many levels of interviews and I had been out of work for so long. I had other job interviews happening and had to take the other job instead of continuing down the process. I always wonder what would have happened had I had the time to wait.
Interview Questions: What do you consider an area of weakness?

title: Volunteer Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Went through 4 different interviews and they were thorough with lots of meetings with all the stakeholders. Heavy emphasis placed on past experiences, it felt like it would be very difficult to get the job without prior experience doing some kind of environmental volunteer coordination work.
Interview Questions: How would you manage in an organization where the majority of the on the ground work is done by volunteers rather than paid staff?

title: Digital Content Strategist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: Emails + Zoom screen for about 30 minutes, the interviewer was not particularly focused on me as an individual or seeming engaged in my candidacy -- she may have been -- however that wasn't my takeaway. I also felt the screening process was designed to identify political sensitivities and leanings. Which is understandable for a progressive organization.
Interview Questions: DEI specific re: white supremacy

title: Campaign Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club

Interview Questions: What does environmental justice mean to you?

title: Political Organizer Interview

Interview Descriptions: Short and easy to complete.  You turn in a resume and then have two rounds of interviews. They were very fair in their questions. Most of the questions revolve around electoral organizing / direct voter contact.
Interview Questions: How would you create a script?

title: Summer Fellowship Interview

Interview Descriptions: After submitting my resume, they had a video interview where they gave an overview of the position, asked what topics interested you, and if you were willing to relocate, etc.
Interview Questions: What environmental issue interests you?

title: Advocate Interview

title: Intern Interview

title: Senior Campaign Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC) in Feb 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I had a first interview with the person that would be my supervisor, then an online group interview with different campaign representatives in different states and then was required to travel to the HQ in DC for an in-person interview. 

I have a lot of respect for Sierra Club's mission but the interviewing process was very disappointing. The communication with the supervisor was very poor, I was asked to travel to DC with less than a week in advance and no flexibility on the day or the time of the interview. 

After the final interview, I never heard back. I had to follow up multiple times to the point of having to reach out to a person above the interviewer to get an answer. More than two months after my interview, I finally learned that I was not chosen. Later I learned that they had already offered the position to another candidate and didn't inform me of their decision. 

I'm not sure how much the HR department is aware of the lack of protocol held by staff leading interview processes. 

My advice: Treat your candidates like human beings, especially if you are a mission-driven organization.

title: Canvasser Interview

title: Operations and Compliance Coordinator Interview

I emailed 2 weeks later, and they revealed to me that in the two weeks I waited to hear back, they chose someone else for the position.

Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at Sierra?

title: Community Outreach Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Richmond, VA) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions:
I applied for the Community Outreach Coordinator Position at the Richmond, Va Chapter and received an interview request two days later. I was told that they were hoping for a fairly quick hiring process and we scheduled my phone interview for a week and a half later. The phone interview went really well! I felt like I connected well with the hiring manager and I was very enthusiastic and showed my excitement for the position. The woman was pretty professional over the phone and I got a great feeling about the office and work environment.

The phone interview happened on a Friday and I received an email Monday evening telling me two things: One that I was qualified for an in person interview (to be scheduled the following week on a Thursday or Friday) and that the hiring manager would get back to me by the end of that current week with a time. Secondly I was asked for a sample of my writing, which I wrote and sent back in a few hours after receiving the email. 

I waited and didn't receive an email by the end of the week and decided to follow-up on Sunday evening with an email inquiry. I was working full time and needed ample time to ask off for the interview that was to be scheduled. I did not hear anything the next day which was a Monday so I decided to give the office a call on Tuesday morning. No one answered so I left a message explaining that I needed to ask off that day if I was going to be able to participate in an in-person interview that Thursday or Friday. I waited and did not receive a phone call or email. Thursday came and went and on Friday I received a rejection email telling me that a lot of people had applied and they decided to go with a more qualified candidate, but that they hoped I would join in their fight by volunteering. They also informed me that because of the amount of applications they had received they wouldn't be able to respond to any application questions based on my application experience. 

I was honestly shocked by the lack of professionalism and communication by their office. I was told that I had qualified for an in-person interview, but wasn't given the curtesy of a time scheduled. At the time I was very disappointed because I thought I wanted this job more than any other job I had applied to. After my experience I realized that it was probably for the best because if this is how they communicate with and treat potential employees, then I can't imagine the lack of communication and order they have in the work environment with current employees. 

My advice to anyone applying to the Richmond, Virginia Chapter is to take it slow, interview the hiring manager just as much as they're interviewing you, and make sure you're aware that a lack of communication may be a possibility.
Interview Questions:
Why do you want this position?
Why do you want to work for the Sierra Club?
Define Climate Change in your own words.
Tell me what your greatest strength is.
Tell me what your greatest weakness is.

title: Deputy Press Secretary Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Seattle, WA) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: The position was initially posted about six months ago.  I applied after seeing the opening two months later.  After another month I found out there was a delay because the person supervising the position was changing.  After another month I was contacted by phone to see if I was still interested in the position.  After several more weeks I recontacted to see what the status was and was advised I'd be contacted for for a phone screening. I was finally scheduled for a 15 minute phone screening a week later.  After doing the phone screening, no contact from them for three weeks.  Found out through other channels that they had sent around internal emails seeking additional candidates after the phone screening.  Called back the interviewer to see what the status was and was advised someone else would contact me.  Subsequently was advised that they were moving forward with other candidates.
Interview Questions: How I would address issues of inclusiveness with a diverse set of stakeholders.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC) in Apr 2016

Interview Questions:
- why i chose my major

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Austin, TX) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was requested for a phone interview a few weeks later. Applications are submitted through the national chapter and you are contacted based on the position you applied for. I had issues with the  local interviewer obviously not thoroughly reading my cover letter and the organization never following up as a whole. This is disappointing since you expect more from a " socially conscious" organization.
Interview Questions: Overall basic phone interview questions: ask about experience and go into an in-depth explanation of the role. Major issue with no follow up.

title: Political Compliance Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions:
I found the job online. I applied and got an email in about 2 days about when to set up a phone interview. We had to do some schedule maneuvering because the interviewer was traveling. 

We had about a 20 minute phone conversation about the position and what it entailed. While I had a lot of experience that would have been perfectly relevant, I was disappointed to find that the job seemed to be geared more towards training than research (the job description made me think it was more of a research position with its emphasis on gathering information, managing reports, etc.). What was also not listed at all in the job description was traveling to do these trainings. 

I was a bit caught off guard and I think that probably reflected in my interview. The interviewer seemed more interested in having someone who had already done actual trainings before.

The interviewer said he'd let me know by the middle of the following week. The end of the following week went by plus a few more days and I followed up by email. In reply I received a form email letting me know I did not get the position. It was a little disappointing to have to prompt them in order to find out whether I should move on or not.

I never met the interviewer in person. Honestly I wasn't too upset because while I had been very excited when I read the job posting, the fact that travel wasn't listed as part of the job made me wary and the emphasis on training during the interview (despite not having been thoroughly detailed in the job posting) told me this wasn't going to be a good fit. It wasn't a lot of trips (5-6 total a year across the country I think) but travel is usually listed in job postings and it seemed very odd that this wasn't at all mentioned if it's required to train people.
Interview Questions: What interested me in this position? Did I have experience in conducting trainings? What was my experience with campaign finance compliance?

title: Campaign Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I was personally recommended for the job by two different people - one inside the organization and one who knew the hiring manager personally. The interview process was pretty protracted - first a one-on-one skype interview, then another skype interview with five different people located in different parts of the country. I expressed interest in meeting in person with the two people located near me, but I never met anyone in person. There were long stretches of the time (weeks) in between each phase, both of which I followed up on, and after all that I never received any word on their hiring decision. (I had to follow up again a month or two later to find out that they'd hired someone else.)
Interview Questions: How would I approach running a campaign in a city that didn't have a typical 'environmentalist' (i.e. white upper-class liberal) population?

title: Political Inern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: One interview, in Lansing. Submitted application, got an email response. Solidified a mutual meeting time to have an interview at the Michigan HQ. Overall a pretty easy process and one that helped the interviewee get to know more about the position and organization.
Interview Questions:
Why are you interested in the position? 
Any politial experience?

title: SSC Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, emailed with the hiring manager, had a phone interview and got the job. Super friendly, very straightforward. Just be enthusiastic and upbeat, they are looking for people that can fit into the culture. Be able to explain why you want the position,  why you want to be at the Sierra Club, and how you will mutually benefit the organization.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at the Sierra Club?

title: Organizing Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Applied online to the job posting on their website. They don't list the closing date for the job and will often keep the job up until they've extended the offer to a candidate. First round interview was on the phone and was a pretty standard screening process to see if you were qualified for the position (and not just good on paper). Second round was in person. Process was VERY slow from application to first interview. From first interview on was quick. Final notice on offer or no offer was also slow. Total process 1-3 months.
Interview Questions: They ran a roleplay during the 2nd round interview that was surprising. Basically judging your skills in conflict resolution and defusing a bad interaction with an employee/volunteer and a member of the public.

title: Associate Organizer Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: Panel interview, with volunteer and 2-3 other staff. Held at the office. Phone conversations prior. Submit examples of previous work (campaign plans, media, etc). Not a suit type environment at all. Be yourself. Know the political landscape.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job?

title: Online Organizer Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I saw some of the reviews on glassdoor prior about how the prospective employer never got back to the interviewee, which in the end was my case. The hiring process was straight forward. I applied online, received and email with a request to set up a phone screening. The phone screening was equally simple. I was then invited again via email to a group panel interview, which was simple and enjoyable. The team was very nice, intelligent and welcoming. The process was very long- 3 months! In the end, I was passed up for an internal candidate. The prospective employer was so taken by me and the recommendations that she introduced me to another department looking for the same position. Although, I had to go through the process again, I was and am very thankful.  

The reason that I'm rating this as a negative experience is because the prospective employer never got back to me after interviewing me for an hour about the new position. After a period, I even emailed her to check in and never got a response. I understand that they are probably swamped with people because it's a great organization, however, this is a simple, common courtesy that too many are letting slip through the cracks. Being left hanging about what is the rest of the timeline and whether or not I am moving to the next step is poor.
Interview Questions: What has been your experience with mass text messaging systems?

title: Associate Organizing Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: Applied for the position in early August. Had a preliminary phone interview/screening one-on-one via phone about a week and a half later. Advanced to the next step of the process which was a group video interview with several higher representatives in the company. Very professional and cordial panel. Although I did not receive the position, I had a very positive experience and rate the organization very highly.
Interview Questions: Q: What experience do you have on campaigns and in the non-profit sector?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: I had one phone interview and one in person interview with the team. The phone interview was brief and was with my potential supervisor. The supervisor mostly asked about my resume and experience in my current position. The in person panel interview was candid and mostly to meet the folks on the team and get to know one another.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Director of Learning and Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted by the "Head of HR" via LInkedIn about a possible new position in L&D for Sierra Club.  This was a person who I had worked with at a prior company.  We scheduled a phone conversation.  The conversation covered the vision for the role and ended with an action item in which I was told he would have someone contact me for a more formal interview in the next few days.  I followed up with a Thank You LinkedIn message.  A week went by, far beyond the time frame I was told, so I sent another LinkedIn message just following up and checking the status of the process.  I still have not heard anything, and this was in October of 2014.

I understand positions may come and go or not happen, but to have a HR Head say they will have someone follow up with you, after they initiated contact and to then never follow up and re-connect is poor customer service and unacceptable.
Interview Questions: No questions were asked

title: Senior Campaign Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: After two phone calls I was interviewed in the national office.  It was simple, quick, and transparent. The individual who would be the manager for the position was clear and honest about the expectations for the role.
Interview Questions: What will it take to win this campaign?

title: Water Policy Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: I head about the Sierra Club through a friend and was very excited to work with a great environmental group. My interview went well and I was hired within 2 hours. I was told I would be a water policy intern working in an open work space (like a think tank).
Interview Questions: They didn't ask anything too hard. They did ask how you previously overcame a difficult experience at a workplace or internship.

title: Associate Organizer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: The manager was unprepared. They interviewed for the same position 6 months apart and never hired anyone. ANYONE. Ask the Sierra Club if they are actually hiring or if the interview is fake. Maybe they are unorganized and rudderless on purpose? Maybe they enjoy meeting overqualified candidates and waste his/her time?
Interview Questions: Are you able to manage your time effectively and without getting into trouble if unsupervised?

title: Research and Polling Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Washington, DC) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Monitor and compile national environmental polls and research for 300 staff members and lobbyists.
Draft a one page report every 2 weeks for Sierra Sync online newsletter with ~400 staff and volunteer readers.
Draft and edit polling briefings and newsletters related to environmental issues, such as climate change.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for the Sierra Club

title: Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Los Angeles, CA) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed by committee of 6. Referred by the predecessor, who was a friend. This interview was farcical and people spent as much time talking to each other as they did to me re: my qualifications.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job?

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Seattle, WA) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: First I had a phone interview and discussed the details of the position, which made me realize the position was pretty flexible as would be the sort of experience where you get out of it what you put into it.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and why you are interested in the Sierra Club.

title: Conservation Organizer Apprentice Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: I sent a cover letter and resume online. Was contacted for a phone interview and then for a google hangout interview. I was told I would contacted within the next week regarding their decision, I heard nothing and even after contacting them, I have gotten no response... Not very professional on their part.
Interview Questions: They mainly asked questions about my previous experience and to expand on my resume

title: Dipl.-Reha-Pädagoge Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process took a long time. I applied for two positions on the same day - one with Sierra Club, and one with another organization. They both responded to me on the same day to schedule an interview. Unfortunately, it took the Sierra Club three weeks to schedule me for an in-person. I was given an offer by the other company in the interim.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Legal Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: good, felt comfortable and the environment was relaxing. They expect you to have the same passion and eagerness to move the company forward and fight there fight. My position was more can you make us more able to fight laws that stop us from protecting our goals.
Interview Questions: what can you bring to sierra club

title: Senior Front End Web Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process took place over quite an extended time-frame. After the initial phone screen, I was given an exercise to complete (a little strange in terms of design...but OK), which took roughly a couple hours. Following that, about a week later, was a second phone interview, and then a couple weeks after that a face-to-face interview in the office, first with a panel and then with the manager and the director. And then finally there was a 2 week waiting period before hearing the results. Not once did I have any hesitation about the place, the job, or any of the several people with whom I spoke--all were completely cordial and professional. And combined with the fact that I particularly respect and appreciate what the Sierra Club does, I very likely would have taken the job had it been offered to me--assuming the salary had been adequate (see previous interview writeup).

Furthermore, even though they did not end up making me an offer, I would have still given the experience a positive rating if it weren't for one aspect. All along the process from beginning to end, whenever Drupal was mentioned I clearly stated that, though I had worked with other CMS's, I had not worked with that particular CMS before (although I assured them I would do all I could to come up to speed prior to starting if selected-- and they always said 'no problem'--including at the in-office interview; in fact they consistently seemed very positive about my suitability for the position. So when they informed me 2 weeks later that they had offered the job to someone else and I asked what took me out of the running, I suppose it was sort of a surprise and yet not a surprise that they said...Drupal! Seems to me it would have saved a good deal of time for all involved if they had first interviewed only those candidates with prior Drupal experience before moving on to other candidates such as myself.

So I have to say the way it was handled was disappointing given the long tradition of Sierra Club membership in my family--as a matter of fact, Ansel Adams was a good friend of my father (true story!).
Interview Questions: Why did you apply to the Sierra Club?

title: Litigation Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2011
Interview Descriptions: At first their was a phone interview with the Director of the department. After that they followed up with an in person interview. The in person interview was with the senior manager and 5 other current litigation assistant employees.
Interview Questions: What, other than those related to climate change, is one of the biggest threats to the environment?

title: Webmaster, Web Training Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: Casual work environment, friendly staff. Web and training related, role so asked to prepare a mock training session. Spent several hours preparing a training outline and development a mock training session that covered how to maintain web content in their Drupal environment. Interviewed briefly with hiring manager, then a panel interview which including this mock training session. 1-1 and panel/training session went well, but when hiring manager did a follow up call to discuss salary expectations, the absolute highest salary offered was 10's of thousands below market rate (even considering this is a not-for-profit organization). Notice recently as of 9/2001 position is still unfilled. Shame. Would consider the role if it was closer to market rate. San Francisco is an expensive place to live and the skill sets required for the job command a much more realistic salary.
Interview Questions: How to's - using their Drupal setup

title: Associate Organizer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume and cover letter by email. Took almost 2 months to hear back from the hiring manager, but once I did, the whole process only took about 1 month. There was one phone interview and an in-person interview, both with several people.
Interview Questions: What is a failure you've experienced and how did you deal with it?

title: Associate Organizer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Jul 2009
Interview Descriptions: I applied but was not interviewed for a few months. First I had a phone interview with 3 or 4 people, then they flew me out to the city where I'd be based for an in-person interview. The dress was very casual - I was glad I didn't wear a full suit! About a week later, they made an offer.
Interview Questions: I was asked to talk about a time I had failed.

title: Apprentice Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2009
Interview Descriptions: I filled out an application with a long essay question/personal statement. My interview was over the phone because the panel interviewers were on the opposite end of the country. They asked me about my interest in working for the Sierra Club, my interest in environmental issues, and my strengths and personal qualities.
Interview Questions: I can't remember... the interview took place a long ago.

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Sierra Club (New York, NY) in Aug 2008
Interview Descriptions: Decent communication beforehand. Easy going interview that encouraged discussion and openness. Good followup questions that allowed me to present my qualifications in a context that was relevant to the position. Naively, though, I did not pick up on several signs that the organization itself is rather dysfunctional in terms of employee well-being.
Interview Questions: Lots of people want to work for The Sierra Club. Why would we select you over others?

title: Media Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Sierra Club in Jun 2008
Interview Descriptions: The interview had two stages. The first was a panel interview with the supervisor and a member of another department. The second stage was another panel interview with the supervisor, the head of the department and a peer level staff member. The work culture appeared relaxed (staff members dressed casually, the atmosphere was casual).
Interview Questions: Discuss a work experience that was challenging.
